awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Unlocking the evolutionary history of Schiedea (carnation family, Caryophyllaceae): rapid radiation of an endemic plant genus in the Hawaiian Islands
awd_abstract_narration:
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Plants exhibit a diverse array of breeding strategies, but the genetic changes and environmental conditions that lead to this diversity are poorly known. Pinpointing these genetic mutations and understanding the environmental conditions that favor changes in breeding system are of great interest to both evolutionary biologists and plant breeders. The plant genus Schiedea (carnation family, Caryophyllaceae) is only found on the Hawaiian Islands and is a model to better understand the evolution of breeding strategies in plants. Among the 32 species of Schiedea, some only breed with other individuals of the same species, others only self-fertilize, and others still are transitional between the two. Additionally, different outbreeding species of Schiedea use different pollinators, including a recently discovered moth found only in Hawaii. This project will apply cutting-edge DNA sequencing and analysis methods to reconstruct the genealogy of Scheidea and investigate the evolution of plant breeding strategies within the group. Data from this project will provide new insights into the evolution of plant breeding strategies that could be applied to crop species in the carnation family, including amaranth, rhubarb, quinoa and spinach. The project incorporates extensive opportunities for education and training at multiple levels, including high school teachers, undergraduate and graduate students, and a postdoctoral researcher. The project will produce educational videos about Hawaiian plants for posting on the internet to inform the public. Researchers will also offer public seminars about Schiedea highlighting their research findings about the group.



The primary aim of this project is to reconstruct the pattern of breeding system evolution in Schiedea (Caryophyllaceae) through an integrated program of field, laboratory, and genomic studies. Nuclear genome sequencing, targeted sequence capture, and Genotyping By Sequencing (GBS) methods will be used to reconstruct a highly resolved phylogenetic tree of Schiedea, identify sources of phylogenetic conflict, and investigate patterns of introgression among taxa. The phylogenetic hypotheses developed will be used to interpret the evolution of breeding systems including transitions from hermaphroditism to dioecy, shifts from biotic to abiotic pollination, and traits associated with pollination biology (including scent and nectar production). Field studies and densely distributed Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms (SNP) markers generated by GBS will be used to test hypotheses concerning the influence of reproductive systems on gene flow, hybridization, and population genetic structure. Data obtained during this project will be applied directly to land management in Hawaii, including the establishment of wild populations of different Schiedea species.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Plants that have evolved on volcanic islands provide outstanding opportunities for understanding evolutionary processes. The Hawaiian Islands are the most remote island chain on the planet and host some of the most incredible plant diversifications in the world. In most cases, these native Hawaiian plants are also highly endangered due to human activities.

 

One of the most diverse groups of native plants found only in the Hawaiian Islands is Schiedea, a genus of 36 species in the carnation family. Schiedea serves as a natural laboratory of plant reproductive evolution: every major type of breeding system known in plants occurs within the genus. For example, some species of Schiedea have individuals with separate sexes while other species have flowers with both sexes present. Likewise, some are capable of self-pollination and others are not, while some species are pollinated by wind, others by moths, and yet others by birds.

 

The central research goal of this collaborative project was to resolve the evolution of breeding systems in Schiedea using a variety of field- and laboratory-based techniques. The project involved six institutions: the National Tropical Botanical Garden in Hawaii, UC Irvine, Chicago Botanic Garden, Clemson University, the Smithsonian Institution, and Oberlin College. We employed a suite of modern DNA sequencing tools to generate an evolutionary tree for all species in the genus using nearly 900 genes. We also undertook field and greenhouse studies to explore breeding system evolution, ranging from cutting-edge chemical analyses of floral scent to field observations of Schiedea flowers in the wild to better understand which moths might act as pollinators.

 

Our DNA-based studies have finally resolved the evolutionary relationships of all species in the genus, which promises to greatly enhance our understanding of fine-scale evolutionary processes. For example, our DNA-based studies reveal a complicated history of evolutionary shifts among breeding systems, and clearly document widespread hybridization among the wind-pollinated species of Schiedea. Importantly, our greenhouse studies of reproductive barriers among species, when viewed in light of our DNA-based evolutionary tree, demonstrate that these barriers are weak among close relatives but are stronger among distant relatives. The strength of these patterns is bolstered by the comprehensive sampling of our studies.

 

Our project has also led to the discovery of two new Schiedea species in the Hawaiian Islands by project partners: S. haakoaensis from the island of Hawai‘i and the enigmatic S. waiahuluensis from Kaua‘i. The latter species is the first species ever found and collected using drone technologies.

 

Broader Impacts

Hawaii conservation workshop

From October 2021 through March 2022, the Schiedea team put on a very successful virtual Hawaii Conservation Workshop. The workshop consisted of 9 meetings, each from 2-3 hours in length, with a combination of prepared presentations and discussion about contemporary plant conservation. Nearly 200 professional attendees from various conservation agencies and institutions in Hawaii attended at least one meeting, and each meeting was attended by at least 50 people. Feedback was highly positive from attendees and organizers. In addition, a draft document was generated during the workshop on best practices in developing and integrating conservation genomics into Hawaiian projects.

 

Tree Thinking workshops

Over the course of the project, 30 teachers from northern and central Ohio attended one of three “Tree Thinking” summer workshops held by PI Moore at Oberlin College. Teachers involved in the two-day workshops learned to read, interpret, and generate evolutionary trees so that they could better incorporate evolutionary trees into their own curricula. Reviews of the workshop were highly positive.

 

Undergraduate training

The award directly supported 6 Oberlin undergraduate researchers and indirectly supported 6 additional undergraduates, all in PI Moore’s lab at Oberlin College. Collectively, these 12 students worked on various aspects of the project, ranging from DNA isolation and sequencing to greenhouse pollen experiments, and they included 10 women, 4 Asians/Asian Americans, 2 Hispanic American students, and one African American. (Note that the award has supported other personnel at other institutions; these are discussed in the other Outcomes reports.)

 

Outreach to the public

The award directly supported the creation of two professionally produced educational videos related to project goals, as part of the “Plants Are Cool, Too!” YouTube channel. These 15-minute videos are freely available to the public and are aimed at a general audience. The first video focuses on the extensive conservation program for endangered Hawaiian plants at NTBG on Kaua‘i, and the second video explores Schiedea plant conservation. Both videos were filmed on location on the island of Kaua‘i.

 

Conservation

The project has directly supported Schiedea conservation efforts in Hawaii. For example, approximately 200 greenhouse grown plants of the highly endangered S. kauaiensis were transferred to NTBG and planted on Kaua‘i, where they are being monitored. Likewise, seed of other endangered species of Schiedea grown by PIs Weller and Sakai has been donated to the NTBG seed bank.
